context: The analyzer was equipped with a motorized interferometer which was able to sweep a wave number range from 900 up to 4200cm−1. It was also connected to a computer using an application software (Calmet) which allows to analyze FTIR spectra obtained by comparison with a spectra reference database. This technique was able to continuously measure the concentration of many compounds that may be present at the outlet of the reactor. The chlorobenzene conversion was calculated from the amount in the inlet and outlet of the reactor and the carbon material balance was systematically checked on the basis of CB converted and CO and CO2 formed. The catalyst regeneration was carried out in a flowing air with the same GHSV (5000h−1) at 350°C for 5h. A blank test was performed at 350°C with pure SiO2 as an inert material and resulted in no chlorobenzene conversion.Catalyst characterization For the catalyst characterization, many techniques like the BET measurement of specific surface area, XRD, TPR, TG/DT analyses and SEM were used. BET specific surface area of samples (fresh, used and regenerated catalysts) was determined in a conventional static volume apparatus (Micromeritics ASAP 2020) operating with N2 adsorption at −196°C.

This indicates a direct relationship between chlorobenzene and carbon, as the conversion process involves tracking carbon atoms through the reaction products formed during chlorobenzene degradation.
